instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMC_LSOC_RST_L: What is SMC_LSOC_RST_L? SMC_LSOC_RST_L is a signal that comes out of the trackpad on Macbook Airs that can reset the SMC.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.SMC_FAN_0_CTL: What is SMC_FAN_0_CTL? SMC_FAN_0_CTL is a line between the SMC and the fan that controls fan speed that is frequently disturbed when someone inexperienced knocks resistors in the area off with their fingernail or screwdriver when unplugging the fan. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Water damage.

I first got 0.48 volt on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.
I've replaced (from donor board):

<TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>
<CHIP>U7090</CHIP>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>

replacing the first two wasn't necessary, but after replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>, <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 18V.

<SIGNAL>CHGR_AGATE</SIGNAL> is 0V with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> present. I lifted <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>CHGR_AGATE</SIGNAL> went to ~16V.
After placing a (new) <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, it went back down to 0V.
Resistance from <SIGNAL>CHGR_AGATE</SIGNAL> to ground is 845KOhm

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_INRUSH</SIGNAL> is 0V

measured 9 Ohms on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>. Seems a bit low, but I dont understand the Inrush circuitry. Some type of protection?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Update: found shorted caps in the <SIGNAL>PPDC_G3H_INRUSH</SIGNAL> circuit (<CAPACITOR>C7130</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7131</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7135</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7136</CAPACITOR>). Not sure if all shorted, but replaced. Short to ground on this rail is now gone,but voltage on this rail and on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 1V.

edit: Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> just to be sure, but no change.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
The original defect was probably only those caps. The problem now is probably in the other stuff you did. Also power up without <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is pretty unsafe and can kill FETs.

Check Voltage on pin 2 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and check resistance between pins 17/18 27/28. Green then orange light present?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
What FETS would be at risk if powering on without <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>? <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>? If so, can you explain why? I assumed that with the gate signal from <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> missing, nothing bad could happen.

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> Pin 2 = 16.1 V
resistance between 17/18 = infinite
27/28 = 20Ohm

<RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> is ~4 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR> is 0.L
<RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR> has a large crack at pin 1

No light on charger

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: 17/18 should have 2-3Ohm so there is a problem there. Shouldn't affect the green light though. Fix the <RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR>/51/52 issue so that pin 17/18 measures 2-3 Ohm again. Also check ACOK. These boards will power on without a green light so if PPBUS comes up at 12.6V again then we can look at the green light issue.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I've replaced <RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR>. Resistance on pin 17/18 is now 3.1 Ohm.


I've replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> again, as I wasn't sure of my earlier replacement there. After that, I got 8.6V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

I replaced the slew of components I took out of the battery circuit, the LVDS connector, <CAPACITOR>C8317</CAPACITOR>, F7700 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> (all were shorted, broken and/or disfunctional).

Laptop is now powering on when I plug it in, and screen is working.

[B]Remaining problems:[/B]
- Power button wont work
- Laptop will turn on, but reboots twice while doing so. When it does get to the OS or ASD, it often reboots after a while anyway.
- Battery not detected (battery could be bad, I dont have a known good one yet)
- Charger light starts green, then goes orange (with or without battery inserted).

Managed to run ASD EFI once, with default options except ram. It throws a few sensor errors (Th1H, TB0T, TB1T, TB2T) but everything else passes.
ASD OS - laptop started rebooting itself when about 75% through the tests. Didnt see the errors.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is now sitting at 8.2V. Board behaves the same as above, but keyboard& trackpad wont work when plugged in. The 8.2V stays.

Couple of measurements:

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>    3,42V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>    3,33V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>    5,12V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>    3,4V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>    3,4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>    3,4V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Power button issue could also cause the shutting down. Could be bad keyboard or the trackpad/flex cable/connector.
Turning on/off 3 times before boot is normal.
PPBUS is at 8.6V so battery data bus is probably ok. Looks like a dead battery to me.
Charger light going green then orange even without battery is normal.

8.2V on PPBUS means no communication from SMC. Could be crap under SMC/dead SMC or crap under battery connector. I assume this is without battery connected.

TBxT are all battery sensors, th1h I think is on the IO board on these airs, LIO finstack sensor. Bad IO board/cable/connector or crap under SMC.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> is 3 Ohms to ground, problem was in <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, which was fine before I hooked that battery up.
I've replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> again, which fixed the short. Both pin 5 and 6 of the battery connector are ~80k now, same as the donor boards I have.
However, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> remains at 8.2V. Could hooking up the battery from this laptop have damaged the SMC? The battery connector looks clean now (after a short UC session), but I neglected to check before plugging the battery in.

If SMC is the prime suspect I'll have to order a stencil for my BGA jig and wait for that. to arrive.

I've added a few pics, might help. I'm ashamed of the way the new soldered in LVDS connector looks, but I'm holding off on adding a new one until the board is functioning properly..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
The SMC was probably killed. Yes a faulty battery can kill the SMC/<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> if the 8V battery voltage shorts out to the data pins. So this battery may be a killer.

It also has quite severe corrosion. The trackpad flex cable/connector will certainly be a problem too.....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Is there a way to check whether the battery is indeed the cause of this without hooking it up? Maybe by attaching it to my lab supply and measuring data lines?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: For the $40 I would just not risk it. Replacing another SMC is a lot more work....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: I'm looking at getting SMC reballing stuff and have ordered a set of new batteries. Thanks so far Duke, I will report back later.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Finally received my SMC jig last week, I got around to taking one off a donor board and reballing that. First time doing this sucked, but I got it on the board in the end. PPBUS is now back to 8.6. Machine runs off new battery and charges it as well.
I also found a short to ground on the trackpad/keyboard conn at pin 18, <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL>, sadly not before trying to run the laptop with that shit connected. Everything still working, so it's hopefully still be ok.
Going to order me a trackpad and flex to see if that fixes the remaining problems. Probably not, I expect the keyboard will be messed up too but we'll see.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Does the short to ground remains on pin 18 when no cable is plugged in?
If so, you have <CAPACITOR>C4836</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> suspected to give <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> a path to ground.
Otherwise, check trackpad/keyboard, I doubt connector problem because there is no adjacent ground pins next to pin 18.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: [USER="296"]jadao[/USER] <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> is fine on the logic board itself (with nothing connected). I might have worded my last post a little unclearly. The short to ground is located on the trackpad pcb. I don't think I'll bother trying to fix that thing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
After replacing the trackpad and flex cable, keyboard and trackpad are now working fine.
This board now passes all ASD tests apart from one: Fan Motor exhaust test 4.

ASD EFI error is:Motor is spinning slower than it should
ASD OS: Motor unable to stabilize between min and max limits

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> at fan connector is at 5.1V.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FAN</SIGNAL> is at 3.3V

Fan actually seems to run fine. It's running silently when laptop isn't  stressed, loudly when it is.

Seeing that I've replaced the SMC on this board, and that one of the inputs of <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR>  (which looks fine) comes from the SMC (<SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL>).. I think I know what the likely culprit is going to be, but I'd really hate pulling an SMC off an otherwise (finally) fully functional board at the risk of making it worse than it is now. Anything else I might do before messing with the SMC again? I've half a mind to run the thing through some serious stress testing to see whether an issue crops up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Before reflowing/relacing SMC: I see in your post that before relacing smc you ran ASD but it only reach about 75% of the test.
Can you check if you might had this error before smc replacement? I don't remember when motor fan is done in asd sequence tests.

Do you have a spare fan to test?

Make sure resistors <RESISTOR>R6065</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R6060</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> measure good an no sign of water corrosion

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I've hooked everything up, assembled the machine fully and ran the tests again. Its passing the fan exhaust (and all other tests) in both EFI and OS versions of ASD.
Not sure if intermittent issue or if something need to be connected for the fan to work, other than the fan itself

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I've run ASD EFI and OS several times now (all default tests) and it's passing everything every time. I've booted up OS X and ran furmark (or whatever its called nowadays) for a couple hours without issues.

Anything else I ought to do before calling this damn thing fixed?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B - no green light. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: This has been back at the customer for a while now and still running fine. Mark as solved please :)
